text:
Does anybody have any best practices for multi-language headers and footers? Trying to figure out the best way to go about building them without maintaining multiple header and footer modules.

Is there a hubl tag or variable that identifies which translated page is being used?

<@UQWGKUEN7>, recently I translated my website to Spanish and didn't want to duplicate all the templates just to have Spanish Headers and Footers. So I used this custom code <https://www.globalizationpartners.com/2018/02/09/multi-language-content-in-HubSpot-part-2/>.

Hope I understood your requirement correctly and this is what you are looking for.

Hey - thanks for the response - I found this too - but I didnt want to rely on the URL. I figured there had to be a way to do it without it.

After searching the interwebs as well as doing some of my own diggin in “developer info” I found
```{% if  content.language.languageTag == 'en-us' %}
    This is English       
 {% endif %}```

Sounds perfect!

I am currently working on a Language switcher (something like attached) and looking for some custom solutions. Let me know if you have done something similar in past.
are you just trying to style the dropdown differnetly?
{{ content.language }} it gives you current language

you should be able to do this with straight hubl

This should also do the trick

```<div class="header__language-switcher--label-current"> {{ locale_name(locale) }}</div>```
<@UQWGKUEN7>, that did work out. Do you have a solution on how to change English - United States to 'English' in the dropdown?

<@USNEEGC4F> Off the top of my head I am not sure if there is a hbul way to get at that info. I am sure that there is though.

My immediate thought is that doing something like this:

```{% macro parseLocale() %}
  {% set region = locale_name(locale) %}
  {% if region == "English - United States" %}
    {{ region|cut(" - United States") }}
  {% else %}
    {{ region }}
  {% endif %}
{% endmacro %}```
but that will only change it on the language switcher and not the content in the dropdown.
I was able to change that. But only the dropdown content is the issue.

So after talking with HubSpot guy for a little bit - he mentioned that there is no hubl way to get at that info.

It seems like JS or making a new module using the html output from the original module is the best way to go about it.
